diagnosis.score_summary: This is a forensic anomaly. The brand is executing with near-robotic consistency across channels, creating a seamless 'Internet Bestie' simulation. The only variations are calculated shifts in social proof and visual temperature, not strategic breaks.

truth_1.headline: The Authority Paradox
truth_1.gap_description: WWW relies on 'Certifiers' (Allure/Derms) to sell the product. PDP relies on 'The Fans' (55k Reviews/Viral Status). You are selling 'Expertise' on one channel and 'Mob Rule' on the other.
truth_1.evidence: Validator Slider: WWW 3/5 (Certifiers) vs. PDP 5/5 (The Fans)
truth_1.why_matters: When the badge represents truth on the site, but the review count represents truth on Amazon, you dilute the source of power. Is this good because a doctor said so, or because TikTok said so?
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You are currently straddling the line between clinical authority and viral fame. The data demands a choice: either lead with the Science globally to protect the premium 'Derma' equity (Option A), or surrender to the algorithm and make 'Viral Favorite' the primary claim on your homepage (Option B). You cannot hold the gavel and the megaphone at the same time.

truth_2.headline: Ingredients vs. Aesthetics
truth_2.gap_description: WWW hooks the user with the 'Feature' (Step into your Era). PDP hooks the user with the 'Component' (Shea/Oils). The website sells a lifestyle; the marketplace sells a raw material.
truth_2.evidence: Hook Slider: WWW 3/5 (The Feature) vs. PDP 2/5 (The Component)
truth_2.why_matters: This subtle drift changes the category perception. On the site, it's a fashion accessory. On Amazon, it's a grocery item. This creates price sensitivity confusion.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: You are selling a 'Vibe' to the direct consumer but a 'Lotion' to the Amazon shopper. You must decide: either strip the lifestyle fluff from the site to match the pragmatic reality (Option A), or force the Amazon listing to lead with the '#VanillaGirlie' narrative to defend the brand premium (Option B). A vibe is harder to commoditize than an ingredient.

truth_3.headline: Public Comfort vs. Private Sanctuary
truth_3.gap_description: WWW signals 'Comfort' (Self-Perception 2/5). PDP signals 'Sanctuary' (Self-Perception 1/5). The site frames the relief as normal; Amazon frames it as a deep, internal escape.
truth_3.why_matters: The emotional payoff is slightly out of sync. 'Comfort' is maintenance; 'Sanctuary' is therapy. Amazon is promising a higher emotional drug than the brand home.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: Your Amazon copywriter is promising a deeper emotional release than your brand strategy dictates. You face a choice: either pull the Amazon promise back to 'Basic Relief' to manage expectations (Option A), or elevate the Global Brand Story to 'Daily Therapy' (Option B). If you promise a sanctuary and deliver a lotion, the magic dies.

truth_4.headline: The Slang Trap
truth_4.gap_description: WWW pushes Formality to 'Slang' (5/5). PDP holds at 'Conversational' (4/5). Surprisingly, the Brand Home is more aggressive with Gen-Z speak than the Marketplace.
truth_4.why_matters: Slang ages like milk. By anchoring the main site in 'Era' and 'Girlie' rhetoric, you risk alienating the older demographic that shops the Amazon 'Staple' aisle.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: You are betting the farm on a specific linguistic micro-trend. The risk is high. You must choose: either discipline the website to match the broader appeal of the Amazon listing (Option A), or double down on the 'TikTok Dialect' across all channels and accept you will lose the Millennials (Option B). Cool is fleeting; clear is forever.

truth_5.headline: Heat Rises on Amazon
truth_5.gap_description: WWW Visuals are 'Radiating' (4/5). PDP Visuals are 'Hot' (5/5). The marketplace is using more saturated, sensory, and tactile imagery to close the sale.
truth_5.why_matters: The Amazon page looks tastier. The visual dopamine hit is stronger in the competitive environment, suggesting the website is playing it too safe.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: Your Amazon presence is more visually seductive than your flagship store. This is a missed opportunity. You must decide: either update the website photography to match the 'Candy Store' saturation of the PDP (Option A), or keep the site 'Clinical-Lite' to maintain medical authority (Option B). In the attention economy, the hottest pixel wins.

marker_1.so_what: Absolute strategic lock. Both channels agree that the power comes from 'The Garden' and the goal is 'The Glow.' This consistency builds an unshakeable foundation for the brand myth.

marker_2.so_what: Perfect alignment on scope. The brand knows it is selling a tool for daily life, not saving the world, and it keeps the velvet rope wide open. This is how you win the volume game.

marker_3.so_what: A united front on safety. By keeping the 'Performance' slider low (Gentle) and transparency mid-range (Explained), the brand avoids over-promising and under-delivering. It promises 'No Harm' effectively.

marker_4.so_what: This is the 'Target Paradox' executed perfectly. It looks expensive (Polished 4/5) but is priced for everyone (Masstige 3/5). Maintaining this tension across channels without slipping into 'Cheap' is a major win.

marker_5.so_what: The brand has successfully killed the 'Corporation.' Both channels speak with the voice of a hyper-caffeinated best friend. There is zero authority posturing, which builds immense trust with Gen-Z.

marker_6.so_what: A flawlessly mixed cocktail. The Lover leads (Sensual), the Jester supports (Fun), and the Innocent stabilizes (Safe). The ratios are identical, meaning the 'Soul' of the brand is intact everywhere.

marker_7.so_what: A minor drift in intensity. The website is screaming in 'Slang' (5/5) while Amazon is chatting in 'Conversation' (4/5). It's the difference between a TikTok caption and a text message.

marker_8.so_what: The signal is strong, but Amazon is turning up the heat. The visual temperature on PDP hits 'Hot' (5/5), making the product look more edible and sensory than the slightly more reserved website.

marker_9.so_what: A nuance drift in the hook. The website sells the 'Action' (Step into...), while Amazon sells the 'Object' (Shea/Oils). It's a small gap, but it changes the purchase logic from 'Do' to 'Have'.

marker_10.so_what: The story is locked. Both channels ignore the 'Founder' to focus on the 'Harvest.' This removes the ego from the brand and places the value entirely on the ingredient sourcing.

marker_11.so_what: The only significant friction point. The website uses 'Badges' to prove worth; Amazon uses 'The Crowd.' One appeals to the brain (Authority), the other to the herd instinct (Popularity).

marker_12.so_what: Total ownership alignment. The brand consistently claims the 'Shea' hill. They are not trying to own 'Dermatology' or 'Fragrance' directly, but the raw material itself.

marker_13.so_what: Both channels are effectively 'Magazines' that sell lotion. The focus is high-gloss editorial content designed to pitch the dream rather than educate the user on the science.

marker_14.so_what: A pragmatic lock. Neither channel pretends this is a medical intervention. They both promise 'Maintenance' and 'Sensory' relief. It's honest, unpretentious functional signaling.

marker_15.so_what: The Amazon listing gets deeper. While the site promises 'Comfort' (I feel okay), Amazon promises 'Sanctuary' (I feel safe). The marketplace is triggering a more primal emotional need.

marker_16.so_what: Identity synchronization. Both channels position the product not as a utility, but as a 'Statement' piece. Buying this lotion is a signal that you are culturally aware.

marker_17.so_what: Safety in numbers. Both channels leverage the 'Majority' dynamic. The message is clear: 'Everyone else is doing it, so you can't be wrong.' It effectively weaponizes FOMO.
